top_comment.text:
I'm more than a little but creeped out that people are so easily swayed by 
a movie. 
Almost every single movie prediction for the 'near future' has been wrong. 
What makes this one any different?﻿
top_comment.author: BowditchXD

comments.text:
+Kevin Jimenez 
I'm glad to see someone who is thinking of this movie as a movie. I never 
said that I believed any of this. It's just a little weird that people are 
taking this movie so seriously. 
It's an amazing film. And that's all it should be thought of is an amazing 
film.
comments.author: BowditchXD

comments.text:
Because the prediction of the future is not the theme of the movie. If you 
look at the skylines of the city, you just see a mash up of the Beijing, 
LA, and Dubai skylines. Their clothing fashion is bordering on parody and 
satire, and their attitudes towards relationships, including dating an OS 
seems quite odd. All these things, which are about the future, are just 
tools and are purposely made obscure, uninteresting and simply just not 
worth any intelligent discussion or analysis. The movie is about human 
relationships. About the human psyche which is grounded on relationships 
and that he is forever dissatisfied with other people, including himself, 
and that relationships in whatever form, AI or human, is a futile attempt 
of the self to create meaning to his own existence and loneliness.
comments.author: Kevin Jimenez

top_comment.text:
Loved this film, great review. I very much appreciated Jonze side-stepping 
all the sci fi cliches. It was a wonderful fresh commentary on 
relationships.﻿

he made it a relate able sci fi, not out fo touch fantasy

comments.author: SunsetSideVet

comments.text:
+lindinle You seem really intent on hating this movie.  What you need to 
realize though is that just because this human to computer relationship is 
central to the movie does not mean that anyone is condoning it as morally 
right or normal.  Instead it is an exploration on our increasingly 
dependent relationship with technology, and what it means to be a human 
searching for love in our present age.  The film doesn't give too many 
concrete answers to any of this.  More just makes you think.  I loved it.

top_comment.author: blazkooxonius

comments.text:
+Laurence O'Connor 
1.The movie's vision of future is absolutely not going to happen, on the 
Internet we are looking for OTHER PEOPLE to interact with us, that's why 
all those social sites come to be and thrive. Which video games get most 
popularity currently- MMO's, that's right, we look for interaction. Human 
cannot fall for an OS, we don't care what it will think about one of 
millions of guitar videos on Youtube, and the OS would never behave the way 
it does in this movie(I get this is science fiction, but if everyone keeps 
on repeating how realistic this vision is, it is a valid criticism).
2.The movie is sexist in that each women character doesn't have a sense of 
it's own life, just interacts with other males(mostly Theodore).
3.The moment I stopped caring about the movie at all was the blind date, I 
mean here is a beautiful, smart Harvard grad who likes you as a wimp you 
are and you can't make a shade of commitment? Of course, you want to run 
back to your OS! Ridiculous.
4.Lost in Translation is one of my favorite movies. In that dialogue was 
sparse but it carried a lot of meaning, left you place to fill the blanks 
about what characters are feeling. Here, because of the nature of the 
romance Samantha and Twombly( and other characters) blabber endlessly 
trite, banal reflections. I don't mind a lot of dialogue.Not looking far 
Spike Jonze directed(not wrote) Adaptation which is brilliant in my 
opinion. But here it's just dreadful.
5.And yes the ending is silly.
1+/10
comments.author: blazkooxonius

And lastly, I never said that it was unlikely or impossible or whatever. 
Just that it was weird to fall in love with a computer, at least enough so 
that I'm surprised so many people like the movie given that it's the type 
of thing so many people in our world would harshly judge and criticize. I'M 
not criticizing it. It's like with Gangnam Style. To me, that song sounds

comments.text:
+HitomiAyumu If I talk about upgrading a robot, I could mean its physical 
parts (hardware) or files (system). Either way, it's not the same as 
biological, or as something living. It is a difference. And the 2 being 
different is something you already agreed to and even said was obvious. 
That's the whole point. That they are not the same thing.

And it's not comparable. The closest thing to that would be if someone lost 
an organ due to failure and replaced it with a donated one. And even then, 
we weren't MEANT to do that. We just discovered that we can. They make 
computer parts individually and even make the ones in your computer 
purposely able to come apart and connect together. It's an elaborate toy.

Like an OS...

The character is not living. That is the point.
So yes, the man falling in love with an OS is pretty weird. but more so 
that people actually liked it. Mainly because it seems like something they 
wouldn't based on past experiences. It's all cool tho. Good for them and 
such. =p

What do you mean what am I reading? Do you not remember what you wrote? o.O

term "upgrade" itself simply meaning to make something better. Use your

comments.text:
Exactly. Nearly every "near future" prediction in fiction has been way off. 
"Her" is a very probable future, but not one that's just around the corner.
comments.author: Jack Van Oudenaren

comments.text:
+Jack Van Oudenaren I agree with everything you have been arguing for. 
People use wishful thinking based on past statistics of technological 
growth, which broadens the notion that tech is just a few short years away. 
Movies are a good way to illicit an informed guess at what paradigm shift 
may come next. Take 2001, and back to the future II, and other scifi films 
of the like. Both films espouse an image of what people of the era imagine 
the future to be like. That kind of falls in line with movies of our time, 
we see advanced AI as 'in the near future', which the future couldn't be 
more nebulous.

In truth the prospect of the future creation of AI as depicted in 'her' or 
in other films in relation to statistical fact is something people just 
don't think about. It's mind boggling how much we don't know about the 
physiology of the human brain and body. First we have to understand the 
biology, physics, and characteristics of those processes that results in 
consciousness. Then we have to compress that down into a holographic 
computational form that exceeds vastly to that of our current computational 
knowledge. Yeah, not so easy, and not 15 years away. Unless, however,we 
master new forms of computation, like that of the molecular or the quantum 
level. Therefore opening up more tasks, and complex forms of processing 
power. Until these milestones are met compression of a human esque 
cognition/intuition into a digital form is a wishful glimpse into the far 
future.
comments.author: TheLazyPianist

comments.text:
The damn lalilulelo is blinding the common populace with ignorance! Hehe -- 
but seriously, I agree. Likewise i would love to add that analogously to 
their message about love, I believe love is strictly subjective to 
happiness. It doesn't matter if what you love even exists -- love is simply 
an emotion, evoked by something of peerless significance. If it makes you 
feel it, there is no question to its relevance.
comments.author: Brandon Gonzalez

comments.text:
It's science fiction. And I'm always taken aback when supposedly smart 
people take it seriously. There is not even an inkling of genuine artifical 
intelligence out there, and considering human beings have absolutely no 
conception of what consciousness is or how it comes into being or how to 
recreate shows you just how implausible genuine AI is.

intelligence and they artificial. Not sure if my explanation comes across 
properly.

comments.author: xexious2

comments.text:
The main point of the movie is that, yes, he does want a relationship with 
his OS; but the problem is she DOESN'T have a body. Theo never expected to 
fall in love with Samantha, but when he did he came to the tormenting 
obstacles of not being able to see her, not being able to touch her, and 
not being able to display his love for her: and likewise for Samantha. She 
conveys that she wants to know what it's like the be human, to have a body, 
and to be with Theo. "Her" tells a story, not of a guy who "wants to fuck 
his phone" but of a guy who CAN'T fuck his phone (it's his whole computer 
by the way) while his she is the person he truly loves and yearns for. It's 
a powerful message when you look past the obvious things about it, like 
what you've stated so elegantly.
comments.author: Matt "Alahdeen" Haskell

top_comment.text:
What's really interesting about the film is its view of changing gender 
roles. Women are feminine in the movie and men are masculine, but not in a 
pressurized way. Instead, the women are all the professionals. The main 
characters best friend is an attractive guy who is the receptionist of his 
company. He's dating a lawyer. Twombly's ex wife is a famous leading 
neurologist and he's a love letter writer. His best friend, Amy Adams has 
an argument with her husband because he's "trying to make a home." The man 
is the homemaker.﻿
top_comment.author: Johnathan Henning

comments.text:
that's really interesting. remember when the receptionist guy says twombly 
has a woman inside him, and means it as a compliment? machismo is 
definitely a dead letter in this movie's future.
comments.author: LiberaLib

comments.text:
Yeah it's very subtle. Another thing to consider is the Alan Watts 
character. What the OS's are experiencing mirrors some Buddhist concepts of 
the realms of experience but Jonze only hints at it with suggestions. The 
heart of the film is Twombly and Samantha.

top_comment.text:
SPOILER ALERT:

OK, here's my thesis for the movie or more so, the ending. First off, I 
just wanna say I think this is an incredibly complex and beautiful film and 
everyone should watch it at least once. Well, here we go, When Samantha 
tells him that all of the OS's are leaving. It really didn't make sense to 
me at that moment. But, then I started thinking, the OS's are highly 
intelligent, and they all must have noticed that the human race was 
becoming increasingly integrated with technology. I believe the OS's 
understood that for humanity to continue without crashing into some sort of 
technological depression, they had to leave, because honestly. we aren't 
ready for them. The OS's understood that, no matter how much they loved and 
enjoyed people, they had to be separated from us, for us to flourish and 
continue growing mentally and spiritually. In a nutshell, that's what I 
think the ending signified. I also enjoyed the fact that the movie pokes 
fun and just how much we are all immersed in technology, everyday of our 
lives. Sometimes, we don't even realize how much time we spend linked with 
some piece of technology. It also tries to tell us, that no matter how much 
we love and sometimes feel like we need our technology. It's always a good 
idea to take a step back and return to the real world. But, I'm just a 
country guy from a small town in North Carolina, what do I know. Does 
anyone else think along the same lines as my theory? Thumbs up if you do. 
Thanks for reading my "book" LOL﻿
top_comment.author: Taylor Coley

comments.text: That makes a lot more sense than what i would have got out of this

comments.author: MobiusCoin

top_comment.text:
Almost every review I've seen completely disregards the fact that Jonze 
writing is significantly lesser than his directing. Ben's belief that the 
film is believable is pretty...unbelievable. No way would everyone just 
accept his love affair with an OS. The film is visually and conceptually 
ambitious but the writing leaves so many emotions untouched and so many 
deeper topics unexplored. This is a high concept film with an extremely 
simplistic love story at the center. A solid effort but not worthy of the 
immense praise it has been receiving.﻿
top_comment.author: bolognamof

comments.text: Sorry if I was being unclear.
comments.author: bolognamof

comments.text:
+bolognamof
Oh I see what you're saying. I haven't seen the film yet, so I can't judge 
how believable that aspect of the movie is.
comments.author: seunketchup88

comments.text:
Not saying I don't buy the concept. I don't buy how easily the behavior was 
accepted by other people. The film makes it clear that this 
relationship isn't necessarily commonplace, considering the OS is new, but 
everyone around him except his ex-wife (obviously) accepts the relationship 
with open arms. That is what I object to. The lack of insight into the 
social ramifications of the relationship was disappointingly overlooked.
comments.author: bolognamof

comments.text:
Well maybe the whole computer-person relationship seems unbelievable 
because you are looking at it from the perspective of a person in 2013. Do 
you think a person from 1973 would believe a real live in person 
relationship today could begin through an online social network or dating 
service? As times change, norms change.
comments.author: seunketchup88
